Typically, left-skewness refers to a distribution where the bulk of the probability mass is concentrated on the right side of the distribution (more extreme positive outcomes), which doesn't directly apply to losses. For losses, a "left-skewed" distribution in the context given would actually imply a distribution where the bulk of the probability is on the less severe loss or no loss side, which could potentially misinterpret the concept as described. Given this, Lottery A could be seen as less left-skewed in the traditional sense because it has a higher probability of no loss (55%) compared to Lottery B's 10% no loss probability, but the concept as applied to losses seems to be about minimizing severe outcomes, which isn't directly addressed by traditional skewness measures.
